title: 5 celebrities who haven't changed their hairstyle since forever
text:
5 celebrities who haven't changed their hairstyle since forever 5 celebrities who haven't changed their hairstyle since forever 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
Anthea Turner went to find love on Celebrity First Dates – but all anyone could talk about was her hair. 
The TV presenter is proud of her trademark blonde blow-dried look, which hasn’t changed a flick over the years. Anthea Turner in 2003 (Andy Butterton/PA) 
And Twitter certainly noticed. 
— Jonathan Cheetham (@Jontroid) September 8, 2015 Anthea "Reliable Hair" Turner #FirstDates 
— Laura Brompton (@LauraLovesBuble) October 12, 2015 Anthea Turner's hair has NEVER changed #firstdates 💇🏼 
— Carla Tromans (@CarlaTromans) October 12, 2015 
She’s not the only one who doesn’t see the need for a change in hairstyle. Here are 5 more celebrities sticking to their trademark look. 1. Rod Stewart. Rod Stewart (AP; Richard Shotwell/Invision) 
OK, so maybe he’s trimmed around the back a little bit. But the rocker found a gravity-defying hairstyle he liked – and then stuck with it for good. 2. Joan Collins. Joan Collins (AP; Ian West/PA) 
Joan has taken an “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” approach to her hair. At 76 and still going strong, we can’t see her chopping off the brunette curls any time soon. 3. Gene Simmons. Gene Simmons (Chris Martinez/AP; Paul A Hebert/Invision) 
The bass guitarist and Kiss singer has been sporting the same helmet of hair since his early Kiss days. To perform as The Demon, he paints his face and puts in a little top-knot, but in his down-time he lets it hang free and fuzzy. 4. Dawn French. Dawn French (Fiona Hanson/PA; Ian West/PA) 
Aside from going for a blunter cut, Dawn has retained her bob and fringe and side-parting since the “dawn” of her career. 5. Brian May. Brian May (PA; Mark Allan/Invision) Share article 
The Queen star’s hair may have switched from blackest black to silver, making him look increasingly like a High Court judge, but the long, bouncy ringlets remain. Promoted Stories
